awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Performance of Reinforced Concrete Structures with Externally Bonded Fiber Reinforced Polymer Composite Retrofits in the 2018 Anchorage, Alaska Earthquake
awd_abstract_narration:
Externally bonded fiber reinforced polymer (EBFRP) composites can be used to seismically retrofit structures in a simple and economical manner. However, lack of documented evidence of their performance during an earthquake still limits their widespread adoption. This Grant for Rapid Response Research (RAPID) will study the effects of the November 30, 2018, earthquake (magnitude 7.0) in Anchorage, Alaska, on the performance of EBFRP composite retrofits in reinforced concrete buildings. The 2018 earthquake, which impacted the same region that was severely damaged by the 1964 Great Alaskan earthquake (magnitude 9.2) ground shaking, provides an opportunity to evaluate the effectiveness of EBFRP retrofits in a high-intensity earthquake and learn about their performance. This study will, for the first time, provide information on the performance of EBFRP retrofitted structures in an earthquake that occurred in the United States. The collected data will contribute to improved building retrofit design standards and construction practices, which will cultivate safe buildings and communities resilient to earthquakes, thus promoting national welfare. The findings will benefit practitioners and researchers by providing a unique data set to benchmark the numerical models used to simulate the response of retrofitted structures. The data will be archived and disseminated through the NSF-supported Natural Hazards Engineering Research Infrastructure (NHERI) Data Depot and Reconnaissance Integration Portal (https://www.DesignSafe-ci.org). The graduate student participating in the project will gain valuable research raining in field data collection and post-earthquake reconnaissance. This award supports the National Earthquake Hazards Reduction Program. 

The main objective of this grant is to collect perishable data on EBFRP response during the 2018 Alaskan earthquake to improve understanding of the performance of EBFRP-retrofitted structures. The data collection activities in Anchorage, Alaska, coordinated with the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), will include the following: (1) a survey to identify reinforced concrete structures that are retrofitted with EBFRP, (2) photographic documentation of damage to EBFRP retrofit systems (e.g., delamination, rupture, and environmental degradation), and (3) identification of in-situ characteristics of the EBFRP utilizing non-destructive (e.g., acoustic sounding and infrared thermography) and semi-destructive (e.g., bond pull-off test) methods. Where permissible, small samples of EBFRP will be collected for chemical and thermal analysis to determine the extent of environmental degradation in EBFRP.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Externally bonded fiber-reinforced polymer (EBFRP) composites are a cost-effective systems used for repair and seismic retrofit of deficient concrete structures. EBFRP composites have been used extensively over the last few decades for seismic retroftitting. However, evidence of their effectiveness in improving seismic performance of concrete structures is mostly limited to experimental quasi-static tests and shaking table tests, with very little data from real-world earthquakes. In this project, we combined field inspection and laboratory testing to evaluate seismic and durability performance of the retrofits. The acquired data provides valuable information that can serve as a benchmark for development of design guidelines, inspection and characterization methods, and accelerated weathering test methods. Findings from this study represent an important contribution to validation of EBFRP long-term performance. This will eventually eliminate some of the current barriers in the EBFRP applicatons as an efficient retrofitting method.

The post-earthquake inspection of EBFRP retrofitted buildings in Anchorage, AK was conducted in January 2019. The magnitude of the earthquake that happened on November 30th in Ancorage was 7.1. In terms of seismic response, ground shaking intensity was lower than the design intensity according to the seismic code. Seven reinforced concrete structures were inspected. Most of the EBFRP found in these buldings was part of the seismic  retrofitting, while others were part of gravity strengthening system. Based on the visual inspection, no apparent damage in EBFRP was observed. Non-structural damage that was observed in some of the buildings involved broken glass panels and concrete cracking. It was concluded that, in general, retrofitted buildings performed well.

As part of field durability testing, we discovered that outdoor conditions may have led to bond deterioration between EBFRP and concrete, as indicated by pull-off tests.  Low bond strength measured between the CFRP and concrete suggests that CFRP bond is more vulnerable to deterioration. The most probable cause of poor bond performance are freeze-thaw expansion stresses of moisture at the interface. This cannot be confirmed since baseline data (collected at the time of installation) and pre-earthquake condition assessment information were not available.  The results of chemical characterization showed that exposure to the subarctic environment did not cause significant changes in the composite polymer matrix, indicating that Alaska?s climate did not have a notable effect on composites? durability.  Scanning electron microscopy revealed only presence of air voids  and non-uniformly distributed fibers, without signs of fiber degradation and matrix damage.

To date, the project has produced  two peer-reviewed publications, and one manuscript that is currently under review. All field data and data generated as a part of laboratory testing have been made publicly available through the Natural Hazards Engineering Research Infrastructure (NHERI) Data Depot and Reconnaissance Integration Portal (https://www.DesignSafe-ci.org)


Last Modified: 10/08/2021
Modified by: Jovan Tatar
